course_title: Social Pharmacy and the Health System 3B

learning_outcomes.description: Describe the aims, methods and theoretical perspectives of the social sciences
Apply the theories and methods of the social sciences to analyse case studies relating to health, illness and healthcare
Explain how our history, experience, culture, beliefs and relationships can impact medication safety and effectiveness, medication adherence and health outcomes

Understand the ways in which culture informs patient centred and personalised care to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and other Australians of diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds
Evaluate how local and global initiatives (e.g. Royal Commission findings, Sustainable Development Goals) seek to improve health outcomes and the provision of healthcare

Demonstrate thinking skills individually and within a group by identifying and evaluating arguments; recognising and considering alternative points of view, and clearly expressing and justifying a position

assessments.due_date: There is an engagement task for each learning week. The task is due 3 pm the day before the relevant tutorial for your group.
assessments.task_description:
There are a series of key readings and tasks to be completed throughout the semester to demonstrate engagement with the course and attainment of learning objectives. The worksheet for each engagement task is provided on the course UQ Extend site.

Each engagement task contributes up to 2 marks. There is an engagement task for each learning week. The maximum mark you can receive for this assessment is 10.

You are encouraged to submit all engagement tasks, but there are a range of ways you could achieve full marks. For example, you could submit 5 engagement task that are each awarded 2 marks, or you could submit 8 engagement tasks—6 x 1 mark plus 2 x 2 marks.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

If you use software to improve your writing (e.g. Grammarly), take care not to use generative AI tools within the software. You need to be able to submit an unedited draft of your work on request.

assessments.task_description:
Engage in an in-class debate with a small group of peers on a topic in social pharmacy or society and health. You are given time in tutorials throughout the semester to work on the debate. While the task is completed within a group, your work is marked individually based on your contribution (30%). If a member of the group is unable to complete their contribution to the debate on the scheduled date, the rest of the group will proceed in their absence.

Submit your debate script with an annotated bibliography by 2pm the day after your in-class debate is scheduled. The debate script and annotated bibliography is worth 10%.

See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for details and marking criteria.

The debate will be recorded and retained as per university policy. The recording will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed if required for the purposes of moderation of marking; provision of feedback to the student; and/or re-marking following a successful re-mark application.

Tutorial Topics

Students attend a two-hour tutorial in 11 weeks of semester:

Tutorial 1: Health and the social sciences

Tutorials 2-3: Obesity

Tutorials 4-5: Opioid crisis

Tutorials 6-7: Indigenous health

Tutorials 8-9: Pharmacy and pharmacists in the health system

Tutorials 10-11: Debate
